awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research:    Integrative analysis of hominid feeding biomechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the forces that shaped the appearance and development of modern humans has been a leading goal of biological anthropology for decades. As technology has improved, our capability to investigate key questions about the factors affecting the shape of our anatomy have advanced significantly. Here, an interdisciplinary team of anthropologists and engineers will use engineering and experimental methods to examine how the shape of the skull has evolved in order to adapt to the forces associated with feeding on different types of food items. Specifically, the researchers will take a highly interdisciplinary approach to examining whether the skulls of these early humans were well designed to crack open and chew such hard, brittle objects. Dietary adaptations are thought to have been critical factors influencing the course of early human evolution, so this research project will provide valuable insights into the functional anatomy, diet, ecology and behavior of the earliest human ancestors. 

With respect to intellectual merit, this project will: (a) examine the functional and evolutionary relationships between diet and skull form, (b) test a leading hypothesis explaining the evolution of the earliest humans, (c) collect and integrate multiple types of raw data critical to an understanding of feeding biomechanics, (d) develop methods for the rapid construction of engineering models that can be applied to research questions in a wide range of disciplines, (e) integrate ecological, comparative, experimental, and engineering techniques for the investigation of evolutionary questions, and (f) rapidly disseminate data, models and findings to the scientific community. 

With respect to broader impacts, this study will: (a) promote interdisciplinarity, diversity and internationalism in science, (b) collect data about skull biomechanics that are relevant to dentistry and craniofacial medicine, (c) support the research of three junior investigators each in the first year of their academic appointments, (d) support female graduate students at several universities, (e) provide support to undergraduates at a university whose student body has a high proportion of minorities, (f) provide training for international students in developing nations (Brazil, Suriname), which will ultimately support the development of scientific infrastructure and institutions in those countries, (g) provide content to an exhibit focusing on human biology and evolution at the Georgia Children?s Museum, (h) using engineering models, limit the need for, or at least increase the analytical power of, future experimental studies requiring the use of live animals, (i) generate data relevant to conservation efforts by documenting the relationship between ecology and adaptation in certain primates, (j) strengthen collaborations between anthropologists and engineers in ten universities and two countries, (k) heighten awareness in the engineering community about how their methods are applicable to evolutionary questions.

por.por_cntn:
This research examined the biomechanics of feeding in our early hominid ancestors, with a focus on early hominids called australopithecines.  It tested the hypothesis that unusual features of the australopithecine teeth and jaws are adaptations for feeding on hard, brittle, seasonally available foods. These foods may have been what are termed “fallback” foods: foods that could be fed upon during periods of scarcity, and thus their consumption may have been selectively important.  As part of this research we had to determine whether there is a relationship between the material properties of foods and the shape and behavior of the feeding system in extant primates.  Living capuchin monkeys are a good model for humans in many respects. Their faces are short and human-like, and they can process very hard foods, such as whole Brazil nuts.

Data on feeding behavior were collected from capuchin monkeys, including the way they use their jaw muscles and move their jaws during feeding on different kinds of foods. We found that the material properties of foods (i.e., how hard or tough they are) had little effect on how the primates chewed, but the external properties, such as size, seem to have a large effect. This suggests that differences in jaw shape among living and fossil primates may not reflect the internal or material properties of the foods that are eaten, but the shape and size of the food objects. This suggests also that it is differences in feeding behavior (i.e., how much incisor biting versus chewing) between primate species might explain their jaw morphology.

We argued that our current poor understanding of how jaw morphology relates to diet in primates might be because we lack good data on variation in jaw bone loading during different feeding behaviors. We presented a conceptual framework of the factors impacting the shape of the lower jaw. Our studies of 3-dimensional jaw movements Consideration of our results suggests that better data are needed on the relationship between dietary categories (such as folivory, frugivory, insectivory), food material and geometric properties, the amount of time/cycles associated with different feeding behaviors (ingestion, premolar biting, chewing), and mandible stress and strain patterns. These data are needed if we are to fully understand relationships between jaw morphology and diet in primates, including living and fossil humans.

We have developed computer models of the skull and jaws of living and fossil primates that will enable us to examine the impacts of changes in feeding behavior on patterns of stress in the jaws. Our ability to relate jaw morphology to diet is important for testing ideas about how climate change impacted our ancestors, including what they ate. Our modeling work will also provide insight into feeding system function in living humans. Living humans have relatively small faces, probably in relation to changes in diet.

In the process of this research, several graduate and undergraduate/college students participated in research. Some of these people went on to positions outside of research, but the majority will be joining the research community. Their research experience at University of Chicago prepares them for contribution to the fields of biomechanics, feeding ecology and the study of living primates.
